You've mentioned the reaction to the television program and to the broadcast of your film on television and to the sales of your book, which are going very, very well, as you mentioned.
But I wonder, when The Producers first came out - Mel Brooks' film - I mean, there was sort of a gasp of shock that you could do jokes about Hitler.
A lot of people still question the taste.

Well, first of all, it was - yeah, I was very happy by the reaction.
I'm also quietly confident that it will be translated in English, even though we don't have a publisher yet.
But to answer your question, yeah, the reaction was actually quite positive.
Concerning my film, I actually used actors to visualize some of the jokes, and some of the press loved that, and some of them were actually critical about that, and you know, I defend it.
I think I did it in a good way, and I think the people who liked it were right.
But it is still of a sensitive issue.
And I'm 33, so I'm of a different generation.
I think there's a different generation now who have to grapple and come to terms with what happened and what their grandparents did.
So I mean, there's a new way of treating and looking at the Third Reich, and I guess I belong to that sort of generation in a way.

It wasn't long after Director Deepa Mehta began filming the movie Water in India that the trouble began.
The film, which started shooting in the year 2000, is set in 1938 as Gandhi's anti-colonial campaign begins to gather steam in India.

Against that backdrop, the movie tells the story of an eight-year-old child bride who suddenly finds herself a widow, and is forced to share the appalling fate of Hindu women whose husbands die before them.
Critics of the film claimed it was blasphemous.
Hindu extremists torched the movie sets in the banks of the Ganges river.
Mehta received death threats.
With more threats of violence, the Indian government forced the India-born Canadian filmmaker to shut down production with only six minutes of footage in the can.
It took five years and a move to another country to finish filming.
Now, Water is in the United States.
It's the third in Mehta's elemental category--the trilogy, rather.
The film and its filmmaker are our guest today.
